StyleSet¶

class aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet¶

An attached type used for accessing CSS like style settings.

StyleSet is the type to access the style properties and information for a QML item. When a StyleSet is instantiated and attached to a QML item it

  • determines the path of the attached-to-item up to its very root (the root of the QQuickItem object hierarchy).
  • connects itself to the singleton styleEngine or its styleChanged signal resp.
  • determines its style properties by matching the attached-to item’s element path against the selector rules loaded from the style sheet.

A style set can be queried for properties using the props property’s various functions, like color(), font(), etc.

The element path is constructed from the typenames and attached “style class” names of the QML and QQuickItem object tree. In the following example the path for each item is added as a comment:

Example:
Rectangle {
  StyleSet.name: "gridline"
  color: StyleSet.props.color("background-color")
}
Note
Style properties should always be accessed through the props property only. Only by doing this it is possible to get notifications about style changes. (The reason is that QML does not create bindings for attached types directly).
The Element Path (UiItemPath)

Rectangle {               // QQuickRectangle
  Text {                  // QQuickRectangle QQuickText
  }
  Item {                  // QQuickRectangle QQuickItem
    ListView {            // QQuickRectangle QQuickItem QQuickListView
      delegate: MyView {  // QQuickRectangle QQuickItem QQuickListView MyView
      }
    }
  }
}

MyView is a user type defined in the module’s qmldir file as MyView. Built-in types like Rectangle or Text begin with QQuick. For debugging purposes the path of an item can be printed to stdout with the StyleSet::path property.

Note
Matching, determining element path and properties may be delayed in case the global style engine has not been initialized yet (e.g. because it is created lazily from a loader). In this case using style property lookup functions like get(const QString&) const or color(const QString&, const QColor&) const may not return expected values until the StyleEngine is actually initialized.
Import in QML:
import Aqt.StyleSheets 1.0
Since
1.0

Public Functions

Q_INVOKABLE bool aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::isValid() const

Indicates whether this style set has any properties set.

Q_INVOKABLE bool aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::isSet(const QString & key) const

Indicates whether a style property key is defined.

Q_INVOKABLE QVariant aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::get(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property named key.

Looks up the style property named key and returns it as is. The output is either a string (QString) or a list of strings (QVariantList).

Note
If there’s no such property returns an invalid QVariant which maps to undefined into Javascript/QML.
Example:
Rectangle {
  color: StyleSet.props.get("clip-colors")[clipColorId]
}

Q_INVOKABLE QVariant aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::values(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property named key.

Looks up the style property named key, evaluates expressions and returns the result. The output is either a string (QString), the resulting type of a CSS value expression (e.g. rgb(), url(), etc.) or a list of these types (QVariantList).

Note
If there’s no such property this method will return an default constructed QVariant which maps to undefined in Javascript/QML.
Example:
Rectangle {
  color: StyleSet.props.values("clip-colors")[clipColorId]
}
Since
1.2

Q_INVOKABLE QColor aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::color(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property key as a QColor.

Looks up the style property named key and interprets its value as a color specification. All common color specs QML supports can be used here:

  • by name, e.g. red, black, yellow
  • by RGB string, e.g. #3f4f5f
  • by ARGB string, e.g. #a0ff0022.
  • then special transparent color
  • CSS color expressions like rgb(120, 64, 230) or hsla(340, 20%, 34%, 0.5).

Style property names can be any string, but typically end with "-color".

If there’s no such property key, the property has multiple values, or the property’s value can not be converted to a QColor prints a warning and returns a default QColor.

The following CSS color expressions are supported:

Example:
Rectangle {
  color: StyleSet.props.color("background-color")
}

  • rgb(r, g, b) where r (red), g (green), and b (blue) can be integers from 0 to 255 or percentage values (e.g. 97%).
  • rgba(r, g, b, a), like rgb(), a (alpha) is a float from 0.0 to 1.0.
  • hsl(h, s, l) where h (hue) is an integer value from 0 to 359 and s (saturation) and l (lightness) are percentage values (e.g. 45%).
  • hsla(h, s, l, a) like hsl(), a (alpha) is a float from 0.0 to 1.0.
  • hsb(h, s, b), like hsl(), but instead of lightness takes b (brightness) as percentage.
  • hsba(h, s, b, a), like hsla(), but instead of lightness takes b (brightness) as percentage.

Q_INVOKABLE bool aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::boolean(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property key as a boolean value.

Looks up the style property named key and interprets its value as a boolean. If there’s no such property key, its value can not be converted to a boolean, or the property has multiple values prints a warning and returns false.

Only the following conversions are supported:

  • “true”, “yes” -> true
  • “false”, “no” -> false

Example:
Rectangle {
  visible: StyleSet.props.boolean("visible")
}

Q_INVOKABLE double aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::number(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property key as a number.

Looks up the style property named key and interprets its value as a number (a double). If there’s no such property key, its value can not be converted to a double, or the property has multiple values prints a warning and return 0.0.

Example:
Rectangle {
  width: StyleSet.props.number("width")
}

Q_INVOKABLE QFont aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::font(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property key as a QFont.

Looks up the style property named key and interprets its value as a CSS like font specification. The font string has the format (with the terms in [] being optional; the order is important though):

Where the following values are defined:

  • style: italic, upright, oblique
  • weight: light, regular, demibold, bold
  • capMode: mixedcase, alluppercase, alllowercase, smallcaps, capitalize
  • hinting: defaulthinting, nohinting, verticalhinting, fullhinting

The size can either be given in pixels or points (e.g. 12px or 11pt). The familyName is any valid family name currently installed on the system, loaded via a FontLoader or via the font-face declaration from a style sheet.

If there’s no such property key, its value can not be converted to a font spec, or the property has multiple values prints a warning and returns a default constructed QFont.

Example for font specs:
italic 14.5pt Calibre
oblique smallcaps bold nohinting 24px Arial

Example:
Text {
  font: StyleSet.props.font("font")
}

Q_INVOKABLE QString aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::string(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property key as a string.

Looks up the style property named key and interprets its value as a string. If there’s no such property key, first value can not be converted to a string (esp. a CSS expression like rgb() can not be converted), or the property has multiple values prints a warning and returns an empty string.

Example:
Text {
  text: StyleSet.props.string("title")
}
Note
The main difference to the generic get() function is that it will always return a single value only, where get() might return a list of strings. This accessor should be used therefore when a single string is expected.
Since
1.2

Q_INVOKABLE QUrl aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::url(const QString & key) const

Returns the style property key as a URL/URI.

Looks up the style property named key and interprets its value as a URL. If the URL is a relative url or path it is resolved with the corresponding stylesheet source the property was loaded from as base URL.

This function understands the url() CSS notation.

If there’s no such property key, the first value can not be converted to a URL, or the property has multiple values prints a warning and returns an invalid URL.

Example:
Image {
  source: StyleSet.props.url("icon")
}
Since
1.2

Signal

signal aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::propsChanged

Fires when properties change.

When ever the StyleEngine reloads its style sheet and property values are changed or new properties appear this signal will be fired.

signal aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::pathChanged

Fires when the path of the item changes.

Whenever the location of the object his StyleSet is attached to changes the StyleSet will fire this signal.

Property

property aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::path

Contains the path for the element this StyleSet is attached to.

The path will look similar to this:

QQuickRectangle.root/QQuickRowLayout/QQuickItem.box/QQuickText

and reads from root to leaf, i.e. the left most token is the element at the root of the QML object hierarchy. The path is mostly useful for debugging purposes.

property aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::props

Contains the style properties for the element this StyleSet is attached to.

Example:
Text {
    color: StyleSet.props.color("color")
}
Note
Due to the nature of attached properties in QML only if you access the style properties by going through the props() method you get a property binding, which will notify in case of style sheet changes. If you access the property settings with color() or font() directly, the QML code won’t listen to style changes.

property aqt::stylesheets::StyleSet::name

Contains the style class name.

The style class name is part of the element path used for matching selector rules. This name forms the “dot” part of an elements selector name.

It is possible to define multiple class names for the same item by separating them with whitespace.

Example:
Item {
  StyleSet.name: "root"
  Component.onCompleted: console.log(StyleSet.path);
}

=> QQuickItem.root

The properties for all matching selectors are merged.

Example:
Item {
  StyleSet.name: "example colors"
  Component.onCompleted: console.log(StyleSet.path);
}

=> QQuickItem.{example,colors}
